conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze the velocity-time graphs and understand the relationship between velocity and position.
The velocity-time graph shows the velocity of objects A and B as a function of time.

The area under the velocity-time graph gives the position of the object as a function of time because velocity is the derivative of position with respect to time, and integrating velocity gives position.
The position s(t) of an object can be found by integrating the velocity v(t).
For object A, the velocity is increasing linearly, so the position s_A(t) is a quadratic function of time.
For object B, the velocity is first decreasing and then increasing, so the position s_B(t) is also a quadratic function of time, but with different coefficients.
From the graph, at t = 0, both objects have the same velocity and position, meaning they start at the same point.
The farthest apart they will be is when the difference in their positions is maximized, occurring when the areas under the velocity-time graphs for A and B are the most different.
The graph shows that the velocity of A is always positive and increases linearly, while the velocity of B has a minimum and then increases.
B has a point where it is moving in the negative direction and then in the positive direction.
The farthest apart they will be is when the difference in their positions is maximized, happening when the areas under the velocity-time graphs are the most different.
The time t_1 is when the velocity of B is zero, and the time t_2 is when the velocities of A and B are equal.
The farthest apart they will be is at the time when the difference in their positions is maximized, typically at the time when the velocity of B is zero and changing direction, which is at t_1.
The two objects are farthest apart at time t_1.
